title: Mark Buckner
text:
Current Research
I use open data to model how the diversity and distributions of solitary bees may change under future climate conditions and in human-altered landscapes. By evaluating how species respond to the changing environment, I aim to provide resources for land management decision-making and biodiversity conservation.
Historically, insect populations lacked detailed, structured, and long-term surveys. The need for more data presents a challenge in prioritizing conservation action. By leveraging community science data and collection records with Species Distribution Modeling (SDM) methods, we can better evaluate how species may respond to a suite of interacting drivers of global change.

  
  
  
  

 Forecasting the Impacts of Global Change on a Bee Biodiversity Hotspot 

The American Southwest is a hotspot for rapid climate change, land conversion, and bee biodiversity. Home to nearly 1,000 species, we are using Joint SDMs to evaluate how global change might impact species richness in the region and how to mitigate the threat.





  
  
  

 Climate-driven range shifts in a rare specialist bee 
Most specialists bees collect pollen from species within the same family of plants. Macropis nuda only collects pollens and oils from a couple of species. Our recent Global Ecology and Conservation publication explored how this species and its primary host plant might respond to the changing climate.

Other Projects

  
  
  

 rlandfire 
rlandfire is an 'in-development' R package for working with the Landscape Fire and Resource Management Planning Tools' (LANDFIRE) geospatial layers in R. The current version allows users to easily call the LANDFIRE Product Services API from within R. 



You can install the development version of rlandfire from GitHub with:

# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("bcknr/rlandfire")

Please submit all bug reports, feature requests, or questions in the GitHub repo.
I am open to collaborators. If you are a LANDFIRE user and are interested in participating, please reach out!

title: Mark Buckner
text:
I am a PhD Candidate in the Danforth Lab at Cornell University, where I research global change ecology and native bee conservation using distribution modeling. My research interests stem from a desire to leverage existing historical records and community science programs to develop resources for conservation decision-making and prioritization in data-poor study systems. 

Born and raised in Colorado's Front Range and educated at the University of Montana, I still question how I ended up out east. But even here, where I'm convinced you can walk little more than a mile before running into a road, I enjoy spending time in nature. When not modeling and mapping species distributions, I can often be found hiking, fly fishing, or  "porcupining."

title: Mark Buckner
text:
Mason Bee Edu is a supplemental high school life science curriculum using mason bees as the focal species. Each of the nine modules introduces a key topic in bee biology ranging from bee phylogeny and diversity to the role of mason bees as pollinators to bee decline and conservation.
The program was created in partnership with high school science educators, education and outreach experts, and industry partners from the New York State Master Teachers Program, Museum of the Earth, and Crown Bees. Each module includes an “educate the educator” background section, a list of vocabulary and resources, and a classroom activity.
Mason Bee Edu is available free of charge at Crown Bees
